title: Lives, dinners, rare enemies and outrunning your mates
text:
Tips for making this report
I’ve created a template for this project, which you can fill in as you make progress. Throughout, lookout for light bulb endowed text boxes (e.g. see Tip 1). These contain suggestions for making a neat, reproducible report that others will thank you for later.
See here for a comprehensive guide on markdown syntax.

title: Lives, dinners, rare enemies and outrunning your mates
text:
Introduction
In this quarto report, you can document your progress on extending McLean, Herberstein and Kokko’s (2024) trophic asymmetry informed life-dinner principle theoretical model.
You could fill out the rest of this introduction with answers to the following:

what is the life-dinner principle and where did it originate?
what question are you testing?
what is your a priori expectation for how this will change the results?

title: Lives, dinners, rare enemies and outrunning your mates
text:
Load neccessary packages






Tip 1: Load your packages early



In the code chunk below, include all the packages you need to generate this report. Putting them all in one place makes it easier for anyone else trying to reproduce your analysis.




Code
# packages go here

title: Lives, dinners, rare enemies and outrunning your mates
text:
Writing math
Quarto uses the same syntax as latex to formulate equations. For example, I can write
\[
W_\mathrm{A} = \frac{1}{\mu_\mathrm{A} + ap\frac{N_\mathrm{C}}{N_\mathrm{A}}}
\tag{1}\]
and reference in-text like so: Equation 1 describes the lifespan of the average antelope in our simple system…Writing math in-line is also possible, you just need to surround it with $ e.g. \(W_\mathrm{A}\) is the absolute fitness of the average Antelope in a population that is predated by Cheetah.
